My first impression of the graph was that I noticed the amount of men's participation in the labor force has declined in every country depicted from 1980-2015.While there are periods of increase for each country, they all show a downward, negative trend. Women's increased involvement in the work force has reduced the availability of jobs for men, who previously dominated most working positions.

The most significant decrease is in the United States. This could be attributed, also, to issues of unemployment that have been prevalent in our nation. While the graph is inclusive of men actively seeking work, discouragement or difficulty finding feasible, well-paid, hiring positions as a result of increased competition could attribute to this decrease. Issues of retirement could also explain this decrease, as much of the baby-boomer generation is exiting the work force. 

I wonder why the labor-force participation in Japan is significantly higher than that of in other countries. I read an article last year that explained Japan's issues of aging population; they have a large population of people over 60, or retirement age, that are refusing to retire and remain in the workforce. replies.name: B
replies.comment info: I would suggest your add actual numbers to your guesses. The Welfare roles are less than they were in the past, because of the 5 year limit on benefits. Perhaps a more important component is Disability. Disability numbers have doubled in the recent past. Anecdotal evidence is that those on disability NOW often have serious medical issues which COULD be handled if the job they get had health insurance. In other countries, where health insurance is a given, these folks would be able to get off Disability - but not here. Yes, America is unique, we don't have guaranteed Health Insurance coverage and this graph shows one of the effects.

name: Moderator Erica
comment info:
It seems we were all disappointed that the U. S. fell so far behind the other countries in labor-force participation rate, especially behind Japan.  We also puzzled at why for most of 1980 - 2017, the rate was declining for all countries.  The reasons most frequently mentioned were technology replacing workers, women working rather than men, and Americans not as motivated to work.  Some said that jobs have been lost to other countries and Americans are staying in school longer.  The graph shows where the data came from:  Alan Kreuger of Princeton University.  Google this and see if you can find what factors Kreuger thinks have most affected the U. S. labor-force participation rate.  Cameron Croom of Raleigh, NC was the first one to hit this reason on the head.

Since we continue to post responses, whenever they arrive, are there more that you notice?  More that you wonder?  Talk to your classmates and even read the moderators’ responses.  Maybe something they say will lead to more things you notice, wonder, and conjecture.  Probe whether the conjectures are possibly true, and if not, change your conjecture.

name: Eleanor English
comment info: Regarding the decrease in male workers joining the work force, I feel as if there are a multitude of reasons, all equally game-changing, that such a trend has ensued. Societally, there's more wiggle room for men to become stay at home dads, caretakers, etc. rather than immediately joining the work force. Fathers taking care of their children and allowing the other spouse to work are becoming much more socially acceptable. Also, in recent years, the education system (at least in the United States) has began heavily pushing for each and every student to go on to a four year college, no matter how much debt you may collect. Thus, causing many to leave high school just to go onto four or more years of further schooling, stunting the amounts of young adults joining the workforce. Nonetheless, we must continue to stay determined to further our education and aim to contribute the most we can to our country's workforce.

replies.comment info: @Eleanor English – “Wiggle room for men” and emphasis on getting more education are definitely present in the US.  I wonder if this is more so in the US that other countries?

name: Moderator Sharon
comment info:
Welcome to What’s Going On in This Graph?.
This month, we have gone international.  We’re examining the working-age population of different countries.  What percentage is either working or looking to work?  (What people are not included in this group?  Those who can’t work or have stopped looking for work.)
How do countries compare?  What has happened over time?
What do you NOTICE? What may this imply?
What do you WONDER? Where could you find the answers to what you wonder?
What’s the STORY this graph tells?  What can you infer that is beyond what this graph shows directly?
The questions are intended to build on one another, so try to answer them in order. Start with “I notice” and then “I wonder,” and end with “The story this graph is ….”
And, your personal perspective may relate the graph not only to its statistics, but also economics, history, geography, or somewhere else.
Then, read what other students have to say.  Possibly, what they notice and wonder will lead you to other insights.  Press "reply" to respond to other comments.
We look forward to reading your discoveries.
